courses.title: The Design of Everyday Things
courses.description: Based on Don Norman's classic book

content.title: Doors, Handles, and Hidden Messages
text-segments: Every day, objects silently communicate what they want you to do.
A door handle screams 'pull me!' A flat metal plate whispers 'push here.'
In this course, we'll explore three fundamental design principles: affordances, mapping, and feedback.

content.title: Story 1
text-segments: Sarah approaches the hotel door.
Glass panel with a vertical metal plate.
The plate looks like a handle.
Her brain screams "pull this!"
What choice did evolution give her?
She grabs and pulls. Nothing.
Confused, she pushes. The door opens.
This is a Norman door.
It gives the wrong signal.

content.title: Story 2
text-segments: Emma approaches the conference room door.
It's entirely made of glass.
No visible handle, no obvious push point.
The surface is completely smooth.
She pushes where others have pushed.
Smudges on the glass are her only clue.
The door swings open.
Poor affordances left her guessing.
Good design would show her the way.

content.title: Story 3
text-segments: Alex finds a sleek modern water bottle.
The cap looks like it should twist off.
He turns it counterclockwise. Nothing.
He tries clockwise. Still stuck.
Finally, he notices it's a flip-top.
The cap hinges upward, not twist.
The bottle's design suggested the wrong action.
This is what designers call false affordances.
Objects that lie about their function.

content.title: Door Design
content.question: Quick question: When you see a door with a handle, what does your brain assume?
content.explanation: Handles suggest pulling. This is called an "affordance" - what the design tells you to do.
content.hint: Think about what action a handle naturally suggests when you grab it.

content.title: Glass Door Mystery
content.question: Why was Emma confused by the glass door?

options.text: It provided no visual clues about how to open it

content.explanation: The door lacked affordances - visual or physical cues that indicate how it should be used.
content.hint: Consider what visual information the door provided about its operation.

content.title: Water Bottle Confusion
content.question: Why did Alex struggle with the water bottle cap?

options.text: The design suggested twisting when it actually flipped

content.explanation: This is a false affordance - the design suggests one action while requiring another.
content.hint: Think about what action the cap's appearance suggested versus what was actually needed.

content.title: What Are Affordances?
text-segments: Those three scenarios reveal something profound about how objects communicate.
Each confusion wasn't random - it reveals how design shapes our expectations and actions.
Don Norman studied these patterns and identified affordances as a fundamental principle of intuitive design.
Understanding affordances transforms how you see every interface, from door handles to smartphone apps.

content.title: Affordances
text-segments: The first principle is affordances - the relationship between an object's properties and what actions they suggest to users.
A door handle naturally affords grasping and pulling, while a flat metal plate clearly affords pushing.
Good affordances are immediately obvious - you know what to do without thinking or reading instructions.
Poor affordances mislead users into taking wrong actions, creating the illusion of user error when it's actually design failure.

content.title: Types of Affordances
text-segments: Objects can provide different types of affordances to guide user behavior.
Visual affordances use appearance - a raised button looks pressable, a handle looks graspable.
Physical affordances use shape and texture - a groove suggests sliding, ridges suggest gripping.
Cultural affordances rely on learned conventions - red means stop, green means go.

content.title: The USB Mystery
content.question: Why does a USB cable never fit on the first try?

options.text: The USB exists in quantum superposition
Poor visual design makes orientation unclear

content.explanation: USB connectors look identical from both sides. Good design makes orientation obvious.
content.hint: Consider what visual information the USB connector provides to help users orient it correctly.

content.title: Affordances in Practice
text-segments: Great designers use affordances to guide behavior without instruction.
A well-designed slider has a groove that suggests the direction of movement.
Buttons are raised to suggest pressing, while flat areas suggest they're not interactive.
The best affordances feel so natural that you don't even notice them working.

content.title: Affordance Check
content.question: True or false: A good affordance requires written instructions to understand.
content.explanation: False! Good affordances are immediately obvious and require no explanation. If you need instructions, the affordance has failed.
content.hint: Think about the best-designed objects you use - do they need labels?

content.title: Complete the Principle
content.question: Fill in the blanks: Affordances are the _____ between object properties and the _____ they suggest.
content.explanation: Affordances are the relationship between object properties and the actions they suggest. This fundamental definition shows how design communicates function.
content.hint: Think back to Norman's original definition of affordances.

content.title: Design Principle Check
content.question: Good design should require extensive user manuals to understand.
content.explanation: Good design should be intuitive and self-explanatory. If it needs a manual, the design has failed to communicate its function clearly.

content.title: Door Study Results
content.question: In Norman's study of door-related accidents, what percentage of people pulled a push door on their first attempt?
content.explanation: Norman found that 73% of people initially pulled doors that were meant to be pushed when the door had a vertical handle. This demonstrates how powerful affordances are - handles strongly suggest pulling, regardless of signage.

content.title: Affordance Examples
text-segments: Great affordances work invisibly - you use them without thinking.
Scissors have finger holes that show exactly where to place your fingers.
A zipper tab moves up and down along an obvious track.
Good affordances make the correct action feel inevitable and natural.

content.title: Affordances in Your Life
content.prompt: Think about an object you use daily that has excellent affordances. What makes it so intuitive?
thinking-points: What visual or physical cues guide your behavior?
How does the design suggest the correct action?
Would this object work for someone who's never seen it before?
What would happen if the affordances were removed?

content.title: Seeing Affordances Everywhere
text-segments: You now understand how objects silently communicate their purpose.
Every handle, button, and switch tells a story about its intended use.
Good affordances guide you naturally; poor ones leave you guessing.
In our next lesson, we'll explore natural mapping - how controls relate logically to their effects.

content.title: Skill Check 1
content.question: A door has a horizontal bar across it. According to the principle of affordances, what should you do?

options.text: Push the door away from you

content.explanation: A horizontal bar (also called a crash bar or panic bar) affords pushing. This is a clear affordance that indicates the door should be pushed to open.
content.hint: Think about what action a horizontal bar naturally suggests.

content.title: Skill Check 2
content.question: You're designing a stovetop with 4 burners arranged in a square. What's the best way to arrange the control knobs?

options.text: In a straight line below the burners
In a square pattern matching the burner layout
In a circle around a central dial

content.explanation: Natural mapping suggests arranging controls to mirror the layout of what they control. Square knobs matching square burners creates an intuitive spatial relationship.
content.hint: Consider which arrangement would create the most natural mapping.

content.title: Skill Check 3
content.question: When should a system provide feedback to the user?

options.text: Immediately when an action is initiated, during processing, and upon completion

content.explanation: Good feedback should be immediate (acknowledge the action), continuous (show progress), and conclusive (confirm completion). This keeps users informed throughout the entire interaction.
content.hint: Think about when users need reassurance that the system is responding.

content.title: The Conversation Continues
text-segments: You now understand how systems should communicate with users.
Good feedback creates confident, efficient interactions.
Poor feedback leads to confusion, errors, and frustration.
You've mastered the three pillars: affordances reveal purpose, mapping creates logic, and feedback confirms action.

lessons.title: Design Magic: Harry Potter's First Four Years

content.title: The Design of Magical Objects
text-segments: Magic isn't just about spells and potions.
Even in the wizarding world, objects must communicate their purpose.
From Hogwarts' moving staircases to the Marauder's Map, magical design follows the same principles as Muggle design.
Let's explore how affordances, mapping, and feedback work in Harry's world.

content.title: Year 1: The Philosopher's Stone
text-segments: Harry encounters his first magical interface: Platform 9¾.
The solid brick wall offers no visual affordances.
No handles, no obvious entry point.
Yet Molly Weasley runs straight at it.
The design principle? Sometimes the best affordance is invisible to outsiders.
The wall's apparent solidity is intentional misdirection.
Only those 'in the know' understand the true affordance: run at it.

content.title: Year 2: The Chamber of Secrets
text-segments: Tom Riddle's diary presents a fascinating design challenge.
It looks like an ordinary notebook - perfect camouflage.
But when Harry writes in it, it writes back.
The feedback is immediate and contextual.
The diary's interface adapts to the user's input.
This is responsive design taken to its magical extreme.
The danger? When feedback becomes manipulation.

content.title: Year 3: The Prisoner of Azkaban
text-segments: The Marauder's Map revolutionizes information design.
Activation requires a password: 'I solemnly swear I am up to no good.'
The map then reveals its true interface.
Dynamic, real-time information display.
Clear spatial mapping of Hogwarts' layout.
Immediate feedback showing everyone's location.
Even magical interfaces need good information architecture.

content.title: Year 4: The Goblet of Fire
text-segments: The Triwizard Tournament introduces complex magical systems.
The Goblet of Fire itself is a perfect example of constrained design.
Clear affordances: names go in, champions come out.
Built-in security through age restrictions.
When Barty Crouch Jr. hacks the system, he exploits a design flaw.
The Goblet couldn't distinguish between three schools and four entries.
Even magical systems need proper error handling.

content.title: Platform 9¾ Affordances
content.question: Why does Platform 9¾'s entrance appear as a solid wall?

options.text: Cost-cutting by the Ministry of Magic

content.explanation: The wall's solid appearance is intentional security design. It hides the entrance from Muggles while still providing clear affordances to those who know the secret.
content.hint: Consider why magical interfaces might need to be hidden from non-magical users.

content.title: Magical Interface Design
content.question: The Marauder's Map demonstrates good information architecture principles.
content.explanation: True! The Map shows real-time information in a clear spatial layout with immediate updates. It's essentially a perfect magical GPS interface.
content.hint: Think about how the Map organizes and displays complex location data.

content.title: Magic Meets Design
text-segments: Even in a world of magic, good design principles apply.
Affordances guide user behavior, whether magical or mundane.
Mapping helps users understand complex systems.
Feedback keeps users informed and engaged.
The best magical objects combine wonder with usability.
